highlighted_text: Wheel.new requires a rim and a tire
even if that object has a diameter
not the class of the object
should not know about the class
if it knew less, it could do more.
Gear doesn’t know or care that the object might be an instance of class Wheel. Gear only knows that it holds an object that responds to diameter.
notes:
It is bound to behavior, not a specific class. It doesn't know, and doesn't want to  know about your Wheel.
It just wants to talk to somebody who understands it.
gear_inches does only one thing now. Calculate gear inches

highlighted_text: The way you manage dependencies on external class names has profound effects on your application

notes:
Removing a dependency from a complex method into a simpler one. This makes the dependency more explicit as it isolates it. It also reduces chances of an error.

We are no longer talking about knowledge of an object but of one of its methods.
Adding a new method enforces single responsiblity on a method level.
Again, the Wheel class is an object itself. It can answer the New() message.

highlighted_text: Using keyword arguments requires the sender and the receiver of a message to state the keyword names. This results in explicit documentation at both ends of the message. Future maintainers will be grateful for this information.
notes: both ends state explicitly what they know. The interface is clear and readable.

highlighted_text: bias should be toward declaring arguments using keywords
free to add or remove initialization arguments
notes:
this isn't strictly true. Adding required arguments will still break dependants/clients code.
What can change is the order, likewise, arguments can also be removed.

highlighted_text: depend on things that change less often than you do.
Concrete classes are more likely to change than abstract classes.

The wonderful thing about abstractions is that they represent common, stable qualities. They are less likely to change than are the concrete classes from which they were extracted. Depending on an abstraction is always safer than depending on a concretion because by its very nature, the abstraction is more stable.
notes:
Abstractions represent categories of things. Types if you will.
They extract what is important and leave out all the rest. The rest, in reality, 
doesn't exist any more. This makes much simpler than concretions, since they need to deal with all of the diry details.

Becuase of all this, abstractions are far more stable.

highlighted_text: These interfaces can have dependents and so must be taken into account during design.
Wheel and on Wheel.new and on Wheel.new(rim, tire)
cluster in Zones A, B, and C.
Zone B classes are of the least concern during design because they are almost neutral in their potential future effects.
your alarm bells should be ringing
When a simple change has cascading effects that force many other changes, a Zone D class is at the root of the problem.
more likely to change than their dependents
messages reflect the living,  animated application.
how they talk to one another
Every object may send any message to any other object
No object stands alone; to reuse any you need all, to change one thing you must change everything.
customers are not welcome to come in and stir the soup.
These methods vary in scale and granularity
Are thoroughly documented in the tests.
Will not change on a whim.
Can change for any reason whatsoever.
May not even be referenced in the tests.
This blind trust is a keystone of object-oriented design. It allows objects to collaborate without binding themselves to context and is necessary in any application that expects to grow and change.
